III.    Facility Identification
The Rupari facility is located at 15600 South Wentworth Avenue in South Holland, Illinois.  Rupari is an importer, manufacturer and distributor of quality pork. Specializing in ribs, both domestic and imported, the company sells to both retail and foodservice customers around the country. 

The NAICS code for the facility is 311612.  A large portion of the facility is refrigerated to preserve products for processing and distribution.   

The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There are two (2) refrigeration systems onsite that are used for refrigerating coolers, freezers, and production areas at the facility. 

The amount of ammonia in System 1 is approximately 23,000 pounds.  System 1 is used for cooling in the storage freezer, coolers, process areas, and compressor oil cooling.  System 1 consists of four (4) high stage compressors, two (2) booster compressors, two (2) evaporative condensers, three (3) storage freezer unit evaporators, eight (8) cutting room evaporators, four (4) holding cooler evaporators, one (1) injection room evaporator, two (2) shipping dock evaporators, one (1) palletizing room evaporator, two (2) receiving dock evaporators, two (2) RTE chill cell evaporators, one (1) RTE package room evaporator, one (1) RTE cooler evaporator, one (1) RTE cooler evaporator before the smokehouse, two (2) tumbling room evaporators, one (1) auto purger, one (1) low temperature accumulator with oil pot and ammonia pumps, one (1) high temperature accumulator with oil pot and ammonia pumps, one (1) high pressure receiver, and one (1) intercooler.

The amount of ammonia in System 2 has been calculated at approximately 9,700 pounds.  Sys

tem 2 is used for cooling in storage freezers, coolers, process areas, and compressor oil cooling.  System 2 consists of two (2) high stage compressors, one (1) evaporative condenser, seven (7) storage freezer evaporators, six (6) blast cell evaporators, one (1) processed product evaporator, two (2) shipping dock evaporators, one (1) tempering cooler evaporator, one (1) auto purger, one (1) glycol heat exchanger, one (1) high temperature accumulator with oil pot and ammonia pumps, and one (1) thermosyphon receiver.

The total amount of ammonia present on-site, including both System 1 and System 2, has been calculated at approximately 32,700 pounds.

An aerial map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A.

VI.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   

This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The next audit of the PSM program will occur by April 20, 2013, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.
A? Employee Participation A? Rupari has developed a site-specific employee part

icipation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses, standard operating proceures, and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  
A? Process Safety Information A? Rupari maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process safety information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed on April 20, 2010.
A? Process Hazard Analysis A? Rupari has updated a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Rupari conducted a thorough PHA study for Systems 1 and 2 on April 9, 12, and 16, 2010.
A? Operating Procedures A? Rupari has updated a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Operating procedures for Systems 1 and 2 were reviewed on April 19 and 20, 2010.  Annually, the operating procedures will be reviewed and certified as accurate.
A? Training A? Rupari has updated a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.
A? Management of Change A? Rupari has updated a site-specific management of change procedure tha

t ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. 
A? Pre-Startup Review A? Rupari has updated a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.
A? Mechanical Integrity A? Rupari has updated a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  The mechanical integrity program was reviewed on April 19 and 20, 2010.
A? Contractor Qualifications A? Rupari has updated a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employersA? safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Rupari and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency response plan and control over entrance into process areas.
A? Incident Investigation A? Rupari has updated a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed.
 A? Compliance Audit A? Rupari has updated a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Rupari PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are bei

ng followed.  The next compliance audit will be conducted by April 20, 2013.  
A? Hot Work Permits A? Rupari has updated a best management practice for hot work.  Rupari reviewed their hot work permit procedures for the refrigeration systems on April 19 and 20, 2010.

VII.    Five-Year Accident History
The Rupari facility has not experienced any accidental anhydrous ammonia releases, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

VIII.    Emergency Response Program
Rupari has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. 

Rupari has conducted training for facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and has interacted (i.e. onsite inspections) with the South Holland Fire Department. 

Rupari has coordinated their ERP with the South Holland Fire Department.  This coordination effort has included providing the agency with a copy of our ERP, and providing a site diagram and hazardous material information, meeting with South Holland Fire Department personnel to discuss the facilityA?s operations/processes, and encouraging periodic on-site inspections and coordination with South Holland Fire Department personnel.

Rupari has determined that the South Holland Fire Department will be utilized for response to all accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. 

The facility has strategically placed windsocks on the corners of the facility buildings for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.  

The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E. 

IX.    Emergency Communications
The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case

of an emergency are available onsite.
 
X.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of Rupari operations. Rupari is currently implementing their Process Safety Management Program. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Rupari.

XI.    Management Program
Rupari has updated a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Brad Young, Plant Engineer, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.
